data.main_text:
How to Analyze NBA Player Stats in R Using hoopR and ggplot2
Posted on
October 8, 2025
by
rprogrammingbooks
in
R bloggers
| 0 Comments
[This article was first published on
Blog - R Programming Books
, and kindly contributed to
R-bloggers
].  (You can report issue about the content on this page
here
)
Want to share your content on R-bloggers?
click here
if you have a blog, or
here
if you don't.
Ever wondered how to pull and visualize NBA player stats using R?
With just a few lines of code and the
{hoopR}
package, you can load real NBA data directly from ESPN and create professional-looking visualizations in minutes.
Here‚Äôs how to build a quick chart of the
Top 10 NBA Scorers (2023‚Äì24)
using
tidyverse
and
hoopR
.
#Load libraries
library(tidyverse)
library(hoopR)
#Load NBA player box scores
nba_data <- hoopR::load_nba_player_box(seasons = 2024)
#Calculate games played and average points
top_scorers <- nba_data %>%
filter(is.na(did_not_play) | did_not_play == FALSE | did_not_play == ‚ÄúFALSE‚Äù) %>%
group_by(athlete_display_name, team_abbreviation) %>%
summarise(
games_played = n(),
avg_points = mean(points, na.rm = TRUE),
.groups = ‚Äúdrop‚Äù
) %>%
filter(games_played >= 30) %>%
arrange(desc(avg_points)) %>%
slice_head(n = 10)
#Visualization
ggplot(top_scorers, aes(
x = reorder(athlete_display_name, avg_points),
y = avg_points,
fill = team_abbreviation
)) +
geom_col(fill = ‚Äústeelblue‚Äù) +
geom_text(aes(label = round(avg_points, 1)),
hjust = -0.2, size = 4, color = ‚Äúblack‚Äù) +
coord_flip() +
scale_y_continuous(expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.15))) +
labs(
title = ‚ÄúTop 10 NBA Scorers (2023‚Äì24)‚Äù,
x = ‚ÄúPlayer‚Äù,
y = ‚ÄúAvg Points per Game‚Äù
) +
theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
theme(
plot.title = element_text(face = ‚Äúbold‚Äù, hjust = 0.5, size = 16),
axis.title = element_text(face = ‚Äúbold‚Äù),
axis.text = element_text(size = 12),
axis.text.x = element_text(size = 10),
legend.position = ‚Äúnone‚Äù
)
Output Example
The resulting chart displays the
top 10 NBA players by average points per game
, calculated directly from ESPN‚Äôs box scores for the 2023‚Äì24 season.
How It Works
hoopR::load_nba_player_box()
loads real NBA game-level statistics.
dplyr
(from the tidyverse) groups and summarizes the averages for each player.
ggplot2
turns those summaries into a polished, professional visualization.
You can easily modify:
The
minimum number of games
‚Üí
filter(games_played >= 30)
The
season year
‚Üí
seasons = 2024
The
statistic
‚Üí Replace
points
with
assists
,
rebounds
, or any other metric.
More Resources
If you‚Äôre into
sports analytics with R
, check out
Mastering NBA Analytics with R ‚Äì Data Science for Basketball Performance and Strategy
$
7.99
Analyze NBA data like a pro. This ebook teaches R programming for player stats, performance analysis, and basketball strategy.

data.main_html:
How to Analyze NBA Player Stats in R Using hoopR and ggplot2

Posted on October 8, 2025 by rprogrammingbooks in R bloggers | 0 Comments

[This article was first published on Blog - R Programming Books, and kindly contributed to R-bloggers]. (You can report issue about the content on this page here)
Want to share your content on R-bloggers? click here if you have a blog, or here if you don't.

Ever wondered how to pull and visualize NBA player stats using R?
With just a few lines of code and the {hoopR} package, you can load real NBA data directly from ESPN and create professional-looking visualizations in minutes.

Here‚Äôs how to build a quick chart of the Top 10 NBA Scorers (2023‚Äì24) using tidyverse and hoopR.

#Load libraries

library(tidyverse)
library(hoopR)

#Load NBA player box scores

nba_data <- hoopR::load_nba_player_box(seasons = 2024)

#Calculate games played and average points

top_scorers <- nba_data %>%
filter(is.na(did_not_play) | did_not_play == FALSE | did_not_play == ‚ÄúFALSE‚Äù) %>%
group_by(athlete_display_name, team_abbreviation) %>%
summarise(
games_played = n(),
avg_points = mean(points, na.rm = TRUE),
.groups = ‚Äúdrop‚Äù
) %>%
filter(games_played >= 30) %>%
arrange(desc(avg_points)) %>%
slice_head(n = 10)

#Visualization

ggplot(top_scorers, aes(
x = reorder(athlete_display_name, avg_points),
y = avg_points,
fill = team_abbreviation
)) +
geom_col(fill = ‚Äústeelblue‚Äù) +
geom_text(aes(label = round(avg_points, 1)),
hjust = -0.2, size = 4, color = ‚Äúblack‚Äù) +
coord_flip() +
scale_y_continuous(expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.15))) +
labs(
title = ‚ÄúTop 10 NBA Scorers (2023‚Äì24)‚Äù,
x = ‚ÄúPlayer‚Äù,
y = ‚ÄúAvg Points per Game‚Äù
) +
theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
theme(
plot.title = element_text(face = ‚Äúbold‚Äù, hjust = 0.5, size = 16),
axis.title = element_text(face = ‚Äúbold‚Äù),
axis.text = element_text(size = 12),
axis.text.x = element_text(size = 10),
legend.position = ‚Äúnone‚Äù
)

Output Example

The resulting chart displays the top 10 NBA players by average points per game, calculated directly from ESPN‚Äôs box scores for the 2023‚Äì24 season.

How It Works

  • hoopR::load_nba_player_box() loads real NBA game-level statistics.
  • dplyr (from the tidyverse) groups and summarizes the averages for each player.
  • ggplot2 turns those summaries into a polished, professional visualization.

You can easily modify:

  • The minimum number of games ‚Üí filter(games_played >= 30)
  • The season year ‚Üí seasons = 2024
  • The statistic ‚Üí Replace points with assists, rebounds, or any other metric.

More Resources

If you‚Äôre into sports analytics with R, check out

Mastering NBA Analytics with R ‚Äì Data Science for Basketball Performance and Strategy

$7.99

Analyze NBA data like a pro. This ebook teaches R programming for player stats, performance analysis, and basketball strategy.

Category: Sports Analytics with R

The post How to Analyze NBA Player Stats in R Using hoopR and ggplot2 appeared first on R Programming Books.
